entry.title: Concentration of Sub-Exponential Random Variables
entry.content:
From Sub-Gaussian to Sub-Exponential

Recall that a random variable XXX with mean μ\muμ is sub-Gaussian with constant σ\sigmaσ if its moment generating function is bounded above as follows:

E[eλ(X−μ)]≤eλ2σ2/2∀  λ∈R.(1) \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda (X - \mu)}] \leq e^{\lambda^2 \sigma^2/2} \quad \forall \; \lambda \in \mathbb{R}. \tag{1} E[eλ(X−μ)]≤eλ2σ2/2∀λ∈R.(1)

That proved useful because, if XXX is sub-Gaussian, then we showed that the tail of its distribution is dominated by a Gaussian random variable with parameters μ\muμ and σ2\sigma^2σ2. In particular, we are able to apply the Chernoff bound to sub-Gaussian random variables and derive Hoeffding inequality-type bounds on the tail distribution.

Sub-Gaussianness, however, is somewhat restrictive. It requires that the bound on the moment generating function hold for all values of λ\lambdaλ! We can relax that requirement just a little bit and demand that the inequality hold for small values of λ\lambdaλ around 000 instead:

E[eλ(X−μ)]≤eλ2ν2/2∀  ∣λ∣≤1b.(2) \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda (X - \mu)}] \leq e^{\lambda^2 \nu^2/2} \quad \forall \; \lvert \lambda \rvert \leq \frac{1}{b}. \tag{2} E[eλ(X−μ)]≤eλ2ν2/2∀∣λ∣≤b1​.(2)

A random variable XXX with mean μ\muμ for which inequality (2) holds is said to be sub-exponential with parameters (ν,b)(\nu, b)(ν,b) for some non-negative bbb (and defining 1/0=∞1/0=\infty1/0=∞).

Before we continue, it’s worth mentioning that sub-exponentialness is preserved under summation of independent random variables, just as sub-Gaussiannes was. In other words, if we have nnn sub-exponential random variables XiX_iXi​’s with parameters (νi,bi)(\nu_i, b_i)(νi​,bi​), then their sum X=∑iXiX=\sum_i X_iX=∑i​Xi​ is sub-exponential:

E[eλ(X−E[X])]=E[∏ieλ(Xi−μi)]=∏iE[eλ(Xi−μi)]≤∏ieλ2νi2/2=eλ2∑iνi2/2, \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda (X - \mathbb{E}[X])}] = \mathbb{E}[\prod_i e^{\lambda (X_i - \mu_i)}] = \prod_i \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda (X_i - \mu_i)}] \leq \prod_i e^{\lambda^2\nu_i^2/2} = e^{\lambda^2 \sum_i \nu_i^2/2}, E[eλ(X−E[X])]=E[i∏​eλ(Xi​−μi​)]=i∏​E[eλ(Xi​−μi​)]≤i∏​eλ2νi2​/2=eλ2∑i​νi2​/2,

which is valid when ∣λ∣≤1/max⁡ibi\lvert \lambda \rvert \leq 1/\max_i b_i∣λ∣≤1/maxi​bi​. So its parameters are ((∑iνi2)−1/2,max⁡ibi)((\sum_i \nu_i^2)^{-1/2}, \max_i b_i)((∑i​νi2​)−1/2,maxi​bi​).

Bernstein’s Condition

An alternative way to characterize sub-exponential random variables is by bounding the polynomial moments of XXX, instead of its moment generating function. Concretely, if XXX is a random variable with mean μ\muμ and variance σ2\sigma^2σ2, then we can show that, if the following condition, known as Bernstein’s condition with parameter bbb, holds, then XXX is a sub-exponential random variable:

∣E[(X−μ)k]∣≤12k!σ2bk−2for k=3,4,… \Big\lvert \mathbb{E}\big[ (X - \mu)^k \big] \Big\rvert \leq \frac{1}{2} k! \sigma^2 b^{k-2} \quad \text{for } k = 3, 4, \ldots ∣∣∣∣​E[(X−μ)k]∣∣∣∣​≤21​k!σ2bk−2for k=3,4,…

Proof. Let’s start from the definition of a sub-exponential random variable and expand the left-hand-side of (2):

E[eλ(X−μ)]=∑k=0∞λkE[(X−μ)k]k!=1+λ2σ22+∑k=3∞λkE[(X−μ)k]k!. \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda (X - \mu)}] = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{\lambda^k \mathbb{E}[(X - \mu)^k]}{k!} = 1 + \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2} + \sum_{k=3}^\infty \frac{\lambda^{k} \mathbb{E}[(X - \mu)^{k}]}{k!}. E[eλ(X−μ)]=k=0∑∞​k!λkE[(X−μ)k]​=1+2λ2σ2​+k=3∑∞​k!λkE[(X−μ)k]​.

By Bernstein’s condition:

E[eλ(X−μ)]≤1+λ2σ22+∑k=3∞12∣λ∣kσ2bk−2=1+λ2σ22+λ2σ22∑k=3∞(∣λ∣b)k−2, \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda (X - \mu)}] \leq 1 + \frac{\lambda^2\sigma^2}{2} + \sum_{k=3}^\infty \frac{1}{2} \lvert \lambda \rvert^k \sigma^2 b^{k-2} = 1 + \frac{\lambda^2\sigma^2}{2} + \frac{\lambda^2\sigma^2}{2} \sum_{k=3}^\infty (\lvert \lambda \rvert b)^{k-2}, E[eλ(X−μ)]≤1+2λ2σ2​+k=3∑∞​21​∣λ∣kσ2bk−2=1+2λ2σ2​+2λ2σ2​k=3∑∞​(∣λ∣b)k−2,

which, when ∣λ∣b\lvert \lambda \rvert b∣λ∣b is smaller than 111, is equal to:

1+λ2σ22+λ2σ22(11−∣λ∣b−1)≤exp⁡(λ2σ22(1−∣λ∣b))≤eλ2(2σ)2/2, 1 + \frac{\lambda^2\sigma^2}{2} + \frac{\lambda^2\sigma^2}{2} \Big(\frac{1}{1-\lvert \lambda \rvert b} -1 \Big) \leq \exp\Big( \frac{\lambda^2 \sigma^2}{2(1 - \lvert \lambda \rvert b)} \Big) \leq e^{\lambda^2 (\sqrt{2}\sigma)^2 /2}, 1+2λ2σ2​+2λ2σ2​(1−∣λ∣b1​−1)≤exp(2(1−∣λ∣b)λ2σ2​)≤eλ2(2​σ)2/2,

when ∣λ∣<1/2b\lvert \lambda \rvert < 1/2b∣λ∣<1/2b. That implies that XXX is sub-exponential with parameters (2σ,2b)(\sqrt{2}\sigma, 2b)(2​σ,2b).

This is a neat result! For example, it is straightforward to see why Bernstein’s condition holds for bounded random variables with the property that ∣X−μ∣≤b\lvert X - \mu \rvert \leq b∣X−μ∣≤b. We proved previously that such random variables are sub-Gaussian. It turns out, they are sub-exponential too!

Concentration Inequalities

Why is this notion of sub-exponentialness useful anyway? Well, for one thing, the family of sub-exponential random variables includes sub-Gaussian random variables. But more importantly, limiting our focus to a neighborhood around 000 enables us to derive more expressive bounds on the tail distribution of a sub-exponential XXX. To see why, let’s first derive the basic tail bound and then discuss a more elaborate bound that contrasts the concentration of sub-Gaussian and sub-exponential variables.

Sub-Exponential Tail Bound

For a sub-exponential random variable XXX with parameters (ν,b)(\nu, b)(ν,b), the following holds:

P[X≥μ+t]≤{e−t2/2ν2if 0≤t≤ν2b,e−t/2bif t>ν2b.(3) \mathbb{P}[X \geq \mu + t] \leq \begin{cases} e^{-t^2/2\nu^2} & \text{if } 0 \leq t \leq \frac{\nu^2}{b},\\ e^{ -t/2b } & \text{if } t > \frac{\nu^2}{b} \end{cases}. \tag{3} P[X≥μ+t]≤{e−t2/2ν2e−t/2b​if 0≤t≤bν2​,if t>bν2​​.(3)

Proof. For valid values of λ\lambdaλ (i.e., ∣λ∣≤1/b\lvert \lambda \rvert \leq 1/b∣λ∣≤1/b), we have, by definition, that:

P[X−μ≥t]≤inf⁡∣λ∣∈[0,1/b]E[eλ(X−μ)]eλt=inf⁡∣λ∣∈[0,1/b]eλ2ν2/2−λt⏟f(λ,t). \mathbb{P}[X - \mu \geq t] \leq \inf_{\lvert \lambda \rvert \in [0, 1/b]} \frac{\mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda (X - \mu)}]}{e^{\lambda t}} = \inf_{\lvert \lambda \rvert \in [0, 1/b]} \underbrace{e^{\lambda^2 \nu^2/2 - \lambda t}}_{f(\lambda, t)}. P[X−μ≥t]≤∣λ∣∈[0,1/b]inf​eλtE[eλ(X−μ)]​=∣λ∣∈[0,1/b]inf​f(λ,t)eλ2ν2/2−λt​​.

When t≤ν2/bt \leq \nu^2/bt≤ν2/b, we can solve the unconstrained minimization problem and obtain:

∂∂λf(λ,t)=0⇒ν2λ−t=0⇒λ=tν2. \frac{\partial}{\partial \lambda} f(\lambda, t) = 0 \Rightarrow \nu^2 \lambda - t = 0 \Rightarrow \lambda = \frac{t}{\nu^2}. ∂λ∂​f(λ,t)=0⇒ν2λ−t=0⇒λ=ν2t​.

Substituting this value of λ\lambdaλ into f(λ,t)f(\lambda, t)f(λ,t) gives the desired result, as in the case of a sub-Gaussian random variable.

On the other hand, when t>ν2/bt > \nu^2/bt>ν2/b, then f(λ,t)f(\lambda, t)f(λ,t) reaches its minimum at the boundary point when λ=1/b\lambda = 1/bλ=1/b. That’s because f(⋅,t)f(\cdot, t)f(⋅,t) is monotonically decreasing in its first argument. Evaluating f(1/b,t)f(1/b, t)f(1/b,t) then leads to:

f(1b,t)=exp⁡(ν22b2−tb)≤exp⁡(−t2b−tb)=exp⁡(−t2b). f(\frac{1}{b}, t) = \exp\Big( \frac{\nu^2}{2b^2} - \frac{t}{b} \Big) \leq \exp\Big( -\frac{t}{2b} - \frac{t}{b} \Big) = \exp\Big(-\frac{t}{2b} \Big). f(b1​,t)=exp(2b2ν2​−bt​)≤exp(−2bt​−bt​)=exp(−2bt​).

Bernstein Tail Bound

We can do something even more interesting if we consider Bernstein’s condition! If we stare at the proof of the statement above that Bernstein’s condition is sufficient to show that a random variable is sub-exponential, we notice an interesting result hiding in there. In particular, we derived, in that proof, the following bound when ∣λ∣b<1\lvert \lambda \rvert b < 1∣λ∣b<1:

E[eλ(X−μ)]≤eλ2σ2/2(1−∣λ∣b). \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda (X - \mu)}] \leq e^{\lambda^2\sigma^2/2(1 - \lvert \lambda \rvert b)}. E[eλ(X−μ)]≤eλ2σ2/2(1−∣λ∣b).

Setting λ=t/(bt+σ2)∈[0,1b)\lambda = t/(bt + \sigma^2) \in [0, \frac{1}{b})λ=t/(bt+σ2)∈[0,b1​) results in the following concentration inequality:

P[X−μ≥t]≤e−t2/2(σ2+bt).(4) \mathbb{P}[X - \mu \geq t] \leq e^{-t^2/2(\sigma^2 + bt)}.\tag{4} P[X−μ≥t]≤e−t2/2(σ2+bt).(4)

Why is that significant? Consider a bounded random variable XXX such that ∣X−μ∣≤b\lvert X - \mu \rvert \leq b∣X−μ∣≤b. We argued above that XXX is sub-exponential as it meets Bernstein’s condition. The tail bound in (4) then introduces a dependence on, not just bbb, as the Hoeffding inequality would (as a consequence of XXX being sub-Gaussian), but also on the variance of XXX!

Because σ2≤b2\sigma^2 \leq b^2σ2≤b2 for a bounded random variable, and for suitably small values of ttt, (4) is never worse than the Hoeffding bound. In particular, when σ2≪b2\sigma^2 \ll b^2σ2≪b2, then (4) offers a much sharper bound on the concentration of XXX.

Example Sub-Exponential Variables

We have already discussed the case of bounded random variables. Indeed, such variables are sub-Gaussian and sub-exponential. Let’s now look at a random variable that’s sub-exponential but not sub-Gaussian: the χ2\chi^2χ2 random variable.

Recall that if Y∼N(0,1)Y \sim \mathcal{N}(0, 1)Y∼N(0,1) is a Gaussian random variable, then X=Y2X=Y^2X=Y2 is a χ2\chi^2χ2 random varaible whose mean is 111. Let’s inspect its moment generating function:

E[eλ(X−1)]=12π∫−∞∞eλ(y2−1)e−y2/2dy=e−λ1−2λ. \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda (X - 1)}] = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{\lambda (y^2 - 1)} e^{-y^2/2} dy = \frac{e^{-\lambda}}{\sqrt{1 - 2\lambda}}. E[eλ(X−1)]=2π​1​∫−∞∞​eλ(y2−1)e−y2/2dy=1−2λ​e−λ​.

Obviously, when λ>1/2\lambda > 1/2λ>1/2 the moment generating function does not exist! When ∣λ∣≤1/4\lvert \lambda \rvert \leq 1/4∣λ∣≤1/4, then we can show that the moment generating function is bounded above by e2λ2e^{2\lambda^2}e2λ2. As such, XXX is sub-exponential with parameters (2,4)(2, 4)(2,4).

As another example, consider the sum of nnn iid χ2\chi^2χ2 random variables. Because each variable is itself a sub-exponential with parameters (2,4)(2, 4)(2,4), we know from before that their sum, too, is sub-exponential with parameters (2n,4)(2\sqrt{n}, 4)(2n​,4). As a result, we can derive the following bound:

P[1n∑Xi−1≥t]≤e−nt2/8,(5) \mathbb{P}[\frac{1}{n}\sum X_i - 1 \geq t] \leq e^{-nt^2/8}, \tag{5} P[n1​∑Xi​−1≥t]≤e−nt2/8,(5)

for all t∈(0,1)t \in (0, 1)t∈(0,1).

entry.content:
Basic Tail Bounds

One of the most basic inequalities governing the tail bounds of a distribution is Markov’s inequality. It says that, if XXX is a non-negative random variable, then its tail probability has the following upper-bound:

P[X≥t]≤E[X]t.(1) \mathbb{P}[X \geq t] \leq \frac{\mathbb{E}[X]}{t}. \tag{1} P[X≥t]≤tE[X]​.(1)

Clearly, this only makes sense if t>0t > 0t>0 and E[X]\mathbb{E}[X]E[X] is finite.

The Markov inequality is tight, in the sense that in cannot be improved in general. To see this, consider the random variable XXX taking values in {0,α}\{ 0, \alpha \}{0,α} with probability ppp and 1−p1-p1−p. A straightforward calculation shows that the inequality in (1) becomes equality.

More generally, notice that:

P[X≥t]=E[X]t⇒∫t∞f(x)  dx=∫0∞1txf(x)  dx⇒∫0∞1x≥tf(x)  dx=∫0∞1txf(x)  dx⇒∫0∞(t1x≥t−x)f(x)  dx=0⇒x=t1x≥t. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}[X \geq t] = \frac{\mathbb{E}[X]}{t} &\Rightarrow \int_{t}^\infty f(x)\;dx = \int_{0}^\infty \frac{1}{t} x f(x)\; dx \\ &\Rightarrow \int_{0}^\infty 1_{x \geq t} f(x)\;dx = \int_{0}^\infty \frac{1}{t} x f(x)\; dx\\ &\Rightarrow \int_0^\infty (t 1_{x \geq t} - x) f(x) \; dx = 0 \\ &\Rightarrow x=t1_{x\geq t}. \end{aligned} P[X≥t]=tE[X]​​⇒∫t∞​f(x)dx=∫0∞​t1​xf(x)dx⇒∫0∞​1x≥t​f(x)dx=∫0∞​t1​xf(x)dx⇒∫0∞​(t1x≥t​−x)f(x)dx=0⇒x=t1x≥t​.​

As such, any random variable with the property that X=t1X≥tX=t 1_{X \geq t}X=t1X≥t​ almost surely leads to equality in Markov’s bound.

From Markov to Chebyshev to Chernoff

A fairly trivial extension of Markov’s inequality is the Chebyshev’s inequality. It is arrived at by a simple application of Equation (1) to the non-negative random variable X:=(Y−E[Y])2X := (Y - \mathbb{E}[Y])^2X:=(Y−E[Y])2 for an arbitrary random variable YYY:

P[∣Y−E[Y]∣≥t]≤Var[Y]t2.(2) \mathbb{P}\big[ \lvert Y - \mathbb{E}[Y] \rvert \geq t \big] \leq \frac{\mathop{Var}[Y]}{t^2}. \tag{2} P[∣Y−E[Y]∣≥t]≤t2Var[Y]​.(2)

Similar to the Markov inequality, we can show that Chebyshev’s inequality is tight in general. It is easy to construct a random variable that results in equality if we notice that we must have X=(Y−E[Y])2∈{0,α}X = (Y - \mathbb{E}[Y])^2 \in \{0, \alpha\}X=(Y−E[Y])2∈{0,α}. For example:

Y={−αwith probability p/201−pαp/2, Y = \begin{cases} -\sqrt{\alpha} & \text{with probability } p/2 \\ 0 & 1-p \\ \sqrt{\alpha} & p/2 \end{cases}, Y=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​−α​0α​​with probability p/21−pp/2​,

One can just as easily extend Chebyshev’s inequality to higher moments, so that:

P[∣Y−E[Y]∣≥t]≤E[∣Y−E[Y]∣k]tk.(3) \mathbb{P}\big[ \lvert Y - \mathbb{E}[Y] \rvert \geq t \big] \leq \frac{\mathbb{E}\big[ \big\lvert Y - \mathbb{E}[Y] \big\rvert^k \big]}{t^k}. \tag{3} P[∣Y−E[Y]∣≥t]≤tkE[∣∣∣​Y−E[Y]∣∣∣​k]​.(3)

Even more interesting is the fact that we can extend this formulation to functions other than polynomials! For example, consider the exponential function:

P[X−E[X]≥t]=P[eλ(X−E[X])≥eλt]≤E[eλ(X−E[X])]eλt.(4) \mathbb{P}[ X - \mathbb{E}[X] \geq t ] = \mathbb{P}[ e^{\lambda (X - \mathbb{E}[X])} \geq e^{\lambda t} ] \leq \frac{\mathbb{E}\big[ e^{\lambda (X - \mathbb{E}[X])} \big]}{e^{\lambda t}}. \tag{4} P[X−E[X]≥t]=P[eλ(X−E[X])≥eλt]≤eλtE[eλ(X−E[X])]​.(4)

Optimizing our choice of λ\lambdaλ so as to obtain the tightest result gives us the Chernoff bound!

We can show that, Equation (3) with the optimal choice of kkk is never worse than Equation (4) with the optimal choice of λ\lambdaλ. Concretely, suppose X≥0X \geq 0X≥0 and that the moment generating function of XXX exists in a neighborhood around 000. Then for any given δ>0\delta > 0δ>0, we can see that:

E[eλX]=∑iλiE[Xi]i!=∑i(λδ)ii!E[Xi]δi≥∑i(λδ)ii!inf⁡k=1,2,3,…E[Xk]δk=eλδinf⁡k=1,2,3,…E[Xk]δk, \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda X}] &= \sum_i \frac{\lambda^i \mathbb{E}[X^i]}{i!} = \sum_i \frac{(\lambda \delta)^i}{i!} \frac{\mathbb{E}[X^i]}{\delta^i} \\ &\geq \sum_i \frac{(\lambda \delta)^i}{i!} \inf_{k=1,2,3,\ldots} \frac{\mathbb{E}[X^k]}{\delta^k} = e^{\lambda \delta} \inf_{k=1,2,3,\ldots} \frac{\mathbb{E}[X^k]}{\delta^k}, \end{aligned} E[eλX]​=i∑​i!λiE[Xi]​=i∑​i!(λδ)i​δiE[Xi]​≥i∑​i!(λδ)i​k=1,2,3,…inf​δkE[Xk]​=eλδk=1,2,3,…inf​δkE[Xk]​,​

so that:

inf⁡k=1,2,3,…E[Xk]δk≤inf⁡λ>0E[eλX]eλδ. \inf_{k=1,2,3,\ldots} \frac{\mathbb{E}[X^k]}{\delta^k} \leq \inf_{\lambda > 0} \frac{\mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda X}]}{e^{\lambda \delta}}. k=1,2,3,…inf​δkE[Xk]​≤λ>0inf​eλδE[eλX]​.

Application to Gaussian variables

Consider X∼N(μ,σ2).X \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2).X∼N(μ,σ2). Let’s derive the Chernoff bound for XXX by optimizing our choice of λ\lambdaλ. First, let’s derive the right-hand-side in Equation (4):

e−λt  E[eλ(X−μ)]=e−λt  ∫12πσ2exp⁡(−(x−μ)22σ2)exp⁡(λ(x−μ))  dx=y:=x−μe−λt  ∫12πσ2exp⁡(−y2−2σ2λy+σ4λ22σ2)exp⁡(σ2λ22)  dx=e−λt  exp⁡(σ2λ22)∫12πσ2exp⁡(−(y−λ)22)  dx=e−λt  eσ2λ2/2. \begin{aligned} e^{-\lambda t} \; \mathbb{E}\big[ e^{\lambda (X - \mu)} \big] &= e^{-\lambda t} \; \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi \sigma^2}} \exp(-\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}) \exp(\lambda (x - \mu))\; dx \\ &\stackrel{y:=x-\mu}{=} e^{-\lambda t} \; \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} \exp(-\frac{y^2 - 2\sigma^2\lambda y + \sigma^4\lambda^2}{2\sigma^2}) \exp(\frac{\sigma^2\lambda^2}{2}) \; dx \\ &= e^{-\lambda t} \; \exp(\frac{\sigma^2\lambda^2}{2}) \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} \exp(-\frac{(y - \lambda)^2}{2}) \; dx \\ &= e^{-\lambda t} \; e^{\sigma^2\lambda^2/2}. \end{aligned} e−λtE[eλ(X−μ)]​=e−λt∫2πσ2​1​exp(−2σ2(x−μ)2​)exp(λ(x−μ))dx=y:=x−μe−λt∫2πσ2​1​exp(−2σ2y2−2σ2λy+σ4λ2​)exp(2σ2λ2​)dx=e−λtexp(2σ2λ2​)∫2πσ2​1​exp(−2(y−λ)2​)dx=e−λteσ2λ2/2.​

Differentiating with respect to λ\lambdaλ and setting it to 000:

∂∂λe−λteσ2λ2/2=(σ2λ−t)e−λteσ2λ2/2=0, \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial}{\partial \lambda} e^{-\lambda t} e^{\sigma^2\lambda^2/2} =(\sigma^2 \lambda - t) e^{-\lambda t} e^{\sigma^2\lambda^2/2} = 0, \end{aligned} ∂λ∂​e−λteσ2λ2/2=(σ2λ−t)e−λteσ2λ2/2=0,​

gives us the optimal choice λ=t/σ2\lambda = t/\sigma^2λ=t/σ2. Plugging this value back in Equation (4) gives the Chernoff bound for our Gaussian random variable:

P[X−μ≥t]≤et2/2σ2et2/σ2=e−t2/2σ2.(5) \mathbb{P}[ X - \mu \geq t ] \leq \frac{e^{t^2/2\sigma^2}}{e^{t^2/\sigma^2}} = e^{-t^2/2\sigma^2}. \tag{5} P[X−μ≥t]≤et2/σ2et2/2σ2​=e−t2/2σ2.(5)

Sub-Gaussian random variables

It is easy to see that, if the following holds for a random variable XXX:

E[eλ(X−μ)]≤eσ2λ2/2∀  λ∈R,(6) \mathbb{E}\big[ e^{\lambda (X - \mu)} \big] \leq e^{\sigma^2 \lambda^2/2} \quad \forall \; \lambda \in \mathbb{R}, \tag{6} E[eλ(X−μ)]≤eσ2λ2/2∀λ∈R,(6)

for some constant σ\sigmaσ, then inequality (5) holds for XXX. We call such random variables Sub-Gaussian with parameter σ\sigmaσ.

Example (1): Rademacher random variables are sub-Gaussian with parameter σ=1\sigma=1σ=1. That is because:

E[eλX]=12(eλ+e−λ)=12(∑k=0λkk!+(−λ)kk!)=∑k=0λ2k(2k)!≤∑k=0λ2k2kk!=eλ2/2. \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda X}] &= \frac{1}{2}\big( e^{\lambda} + e^{-\lambda} \big) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \big( \sum_{k=0} \frac{\lambda^k}{k!} + \frac{(-\lambda)^k}{k!} \big) \\ &= \sum_{k=0} \frac{\lambda^{2k}}{(2k)!} \\ &\leq \sum_{k=0} \frac{\lambda^{2k}}{2^k k!} = e^{\lambda^2/2}. \end{aligned} E[eλX]​=21​(eλ+e−λ)=21​(k=0∑​k!λk​+k!(−λ)k​)=k=0∑​(2k)!λ2k​≤k=0∑​2kk!λ2k​=eλ2/2.​

Example (2): Any zero-mean bounded variable XXX supported on the interval [a,b][a, b][a,b] is sub-Gaussian with parameter at most σ=b−a\sigma=b-aσ=b−a.

Proving this requires the symmetrization argument. We first introduce an independent copy of XXX and call it X′X^\primeX′, and let γ\gammaγ be a Rademacher random variable. By the convexity of the exponential and Jensen’s inequality, we can write:

E[eλX]≤EX,X′,γ[eλγ(X−X′)]≤EX,X′[eλ2(X−X′)2/2]≤eλ2(b−a)2/2. \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda X}] \leq \mathbb{E}_{X, X^\prime, \gamma} \big[ e^{\lambda \gamma (X - X^\prime)} \big] \leq \mathbb{E}_{X, X^\prime} \big[ e^{\lambda^2 (X - X^\prime)^2 /2} \big] \leq e^{\lambda^2 (b - a)^2/2}. ψ(λ)=log⁡E[eλX]. \psi(\lambda) = \log \mathbb{E}[e^{\lambda X}]. ψ(λ)=logE[eλX].

entry.title: Johnson-Lindenstrauss Transform
entry.content:
Say you have a set V\mathcal{V}V of mmm points in some high-dimensional space Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn. Let’s say nnn is really large, making any subsequent computation on the m×nm \times nm×n data matrix (let’s call it XXX) rather expensive. This is where dimensionality reduction can prove helpful.

We know how to apply a number of tricks from basic linear algebra to do just that. For example, we can obtain a low-rank approximation of XXX by the simple act of projecting it onto the subspace spanned by its top kkk singular vectors. That gives a matrix X~\tilde{X}X~ with rank at most kkk such that ∥X−X~∥F\lVert X - \tilde{X} \rVert_F∥X−X~∥F​ is small.

In some applications, it’s not enough to approximately preserve the Frobenius norm of XXX. For example, we may be interested, instead, in approximately preserving the pairwise Euclidean distance between the mmm points—a property that is important in Nearest Neighbor Search. That is, if x~i∈Rk\tilde{x}_i \in \mathbb{R}^kx~i​∈Rk is the image of x∈Vx \in \mathcal{V}x∈V under our dimensionality reducing transformation (where presumably k≪nk \ll nk≪n), then we want the following to hold for all 1≤i≤j≤m1 \leq i \leq j \leq m1≤i≤j≤m:

(1−ϵ)∥xi−xj∥22≤∥x~i−x~j∥22≤(1+ϵ)∥xi−xj∥22,(1) (1-\epsilon) \lVert x_i - x_j \rVert_2^2 \leq \lVert \tilde{x}_i - \tilde{x}_j \rVert_2^2 \leq (1+\epsilon) \lVert x_i - x_j \rVert_2^2, \tag{1} (1−ϵ)∥xi​−xj​∥22​≤∥x~i​−x~j​∥22​≤(1+ϵ)∥xi​−xj​∥22​,(1)

for some ϵ∈(0,1)\epsilon \in (0, 1)ϵ∈(0,1). Occasionally I’ll write the above inequalities more compactly as:

∥x~i−x~j∥22=(1±ϵ)∥xi−xj∥22.(2) \lVert \tilde{x}_i - \tilde{x}_j\lVert_2^2 = (1\pm \epsilon) \lVert x_i - x_j \rVert_2^2. \tag{2} ∥x~i​−x~j​∥22​=(1±ϵ)∥xi​−xj​∥22​.(2)

It’s fairly easy to see that a bound on the Frobenius norm does not necessarily translate to this (1±ϵ)(1 \pm \epsilon)(1±ϵ)-approximation of pairwise Euclidean distances! We might in fact be able to lower the error in the Frobenius norm by moving some points farther from each other and others closer to each other. In other words, approximately preserving a global notion of distance is not equivalent to approximately preserving our local distances required by Equation (2).

That’s where the seminal result due to Johnson and Lindenstrauss comes into the picture. It’s led to a series of works that offer a simple and elegant, linear and randomized machinery to reduce dimensionality and yet approximately preserve local distances. These probabilistic algorithms play an important role in randomized numerical linear algebra such as subspace embedding. So it’s worth reviewing the basics. Let’s dive into it.

The Johnson-Lindenstrauss Transform

Distributional Johnson-Lindenstrauss (JL) Lemma. For every positive nnn and ϵ,δ∈(0,1)\epsilon, \delta \in (0, 1)ϵ,δ∈(0,1), there is a distribution Π\PiΠ over linear maps in Rk×n\mathbb{R}^{k \times n}Rk×n with k=Θ(ϵ−2log⁡1δ)k = \Theta(\epsilon^{-2} \log \frac{1}{\delta})k=Θ(ϵ−2logδ1​), such that, for all u∈Rnu \in \mathbb{R}^nu∈Rn:

PS∼Π[∥Su∥22=(1±ϵ)∥u∥22]≥1−δ.(3) \mathbb{P}_{S \sim \Pi}\big[ \lVert Su \rVert_2^2 = (1 \pm \epsilon) \lVert u \rVert_2^2 \big] \geq 1 - \delta. \tag{3} PS∼Π​[∥Su∥22​=(1±ϵ)∥u∥22​]≥1−δ.(3)

I’ll refer to Equation (3) as the JL Property and say that a random matrix SSS has the JL property if Equation (2) holds for the distribution over SSS’s.

How does this lemma relate to Equation (2) and our search for a transformation that preserves pairwise Euclidean distances? By setting u=(xi−xj)/∥xi−xj∥2u = (x_i - x_j) / \lVert x_i - x_j \rVert_2u=(xi​−xj​)/∥xi​−xj​∥2​ for all xi,xj∈Vx_i, x_j \in \mathcal{V}xi​,xj​∈V, and choosing δ\deltaδ to be at most δ/(m2)\delta/{m \choose 2}δ/(2m​), we can apply the union bound and obtain that ∥Sxi−Sxj∥=(1±ϵ)∥xi−xj∥\lVert Sx_i - Sx_j \lVert = (1\pm \epsilon) \lVert x_i - x_j \rVert∥Sxi​−Sxj​∥=(1±ϵ)∥xi​−xj​∥ with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ. In fact, that procedure gives the more familiar version of the Johnson-Lindenstrauss lemma, stated below:

Johnson-Lindenstrauss Lemma. Given a set V\mathcal{V}V of mmm points in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn and ϵ∈(0,1)\epsilon \in (0, 1)ϵ∈(0,1), there exists a mapping f:Rn→Rkf: \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^kf:Rn→Rk where k=Ω(ϵ−2log⁡mδ)k = \Omega(\epsilon^{-2} \log \frac{m}{\delta})k=Ω(ϵ−2logδm​), such that for all pairs xi,xj∈Vx_i, x_j \in \mathcal{V}xi​,xj​∈V, ∥f(xi)−f(xj)∥22=(1±ϵ)∥xi−xj∥22\lVert f(x_i) - f(x_j) \lVert_2^2 = (1 \pm \epsilon) \lVert x_i - x_j \lVert_2^2∥f(xi​)−f(xj​)∥22​=(1±ϵ)∥xi​−xj​∥22​.

Before we continue, I should mention a neat consequence of the distributional JL lemma. In particular, inner products too are approximately preserved! Concretely, if points uuu and vvv on the unit sphere Sn−1\mathbb{S}^{n-1}Sn−1 then:

P[∣⟨Su,Sv⟩−⟨u,v⟩∣≤ϵ]≥1−δ.(4) \mathbb{P} \Big[ \big\lvert \langle Su, Sv \rangle - \langle u, v \rangle \big\rvert \leq \epsilon \big] \geq 1 - \delta. \tag{4} P[∣∣∣​⟨Su,Sv⟩−⟨u,v⟩∣∣∣​≤ϵ]≥1−δ.(4)

That’s because, we can write:

4(⟨Su,Sv⟩−⟨u,v⟩)⏟α=∥Su+Sv∥22−∥Su−Sv∥22−4⟨u,v⟩, 4\underbrace{\big( \langle Su, Sv \rangle - \langle u, v \rangle \big)}_{\alpha} = \lVert Su + Sv \rVert_2^2 -\lVert Su - Sv \rVert_2^2 - 4\langle u, v \rangle, 4α(⟨Su,Sv⟩−⟨u,v⟩)​​=∥Su+Sv∥22​−∥Su−Sv∥22​−4⟨u,v⟩,

so that, with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, we have that:

(1−ϵ)∥u+v∥22−(1+ϵ)∥u−v∥22−4⟨u,v⟩≤4α≤(1+ϵ)∥u+v∥22−(1−ϵ)∥u−v∥22−4⟨u,v⟩⇒−ϵ(2∥u∥22+2∥v∥22)≤4α≤ϵ(2∥u∥22+2∥v∥22)⇒−ϵ≤α≤ϵ. \begin{aligned} (1 - \epsilon) &\lVert u + v \lVert_2^2 - (1 + \epsilon) \lVert u - v \rVert_2^2 - 4\langle u, v \rangle \\ &\leq 4\alpha \leq (1 + \epsilon) \lVert u+v \lVert_2^2 - (1 - \epsilon) \lVert u - v \rVert_2^2 - 4\langle u, v \rangle \Rightarrow \\ -\epsilon &(2 \lVert u \rVert_2^2 + 2 \lVert v \rVert_2^2) \leq 4\alpha \leq\epsilon (2 \lVert u \rVert_2^2 + 2 \lVert v \rVert_2^2) \Rightarrow -\epsilon \leq \alpha \leq \epsilon. \end{aligned} (1−ϵ)−ϵ​∥u+v∥22​−(1+ϵ)∥u−v∥22​−4⟨u,v⟩≤4α≤(1+ϵ)∥u+v∥22​−(1−ϵ)∥u−v∥22​−4⟨u,v⟩⇒(2∥u∥22​+2∥v∥22​)≤4α≤ϵ(2∥u∥22​+2∥v∥22​)⇒−ϵ≤α≤ϵ.​

More generally, for arbitrary x,y∈Rnx, y \in \mathbb{R}^nx,y∈Rn, the following statement holds:

P[∣⟨Sx,Sy⟩−⟨x,y⟩∣≤ϵ∥x∥2∥y∥2]≥1−δ, \mathbb{P} \Big[ \big\lvert \langle Sx, Sy \rangle - \langle x, y \rangle \big\rvert \leq \epsilon \lVert x \rVert_2 \lVert y \rVert_2 \big] \geq 1 - \delta, P[∣∣∣​⟨Sx,Sy⟩−⟨x,y⟩∣∣∣​≤ϵ∥x∥2​∥y∥2​]≥1−δ,

which follows by defining u=x/∥x∥2u=x/\lVert x \rVert_2u=x/∥x∥2​ and v=y/∥y∥2v=y/\lVert y\rVert_2v=y/∥y∥2​ in Equation (4).

Example Construction

Let S=1kR∈Rk×nS=\frac{1}{\sqrt{k}}R \in \mathbb{R}^{k \times n}S=k​1​R∈Rk×n where the entries of RRR are iid standard normal random variables. Then SSS has the JL property.


Proof: First consider the case of u∈Sn−1u \in \mathbb{S}^{n-1}u∈Sn−1. Notice that SuSuSu is a kkk-dimensional Gaussian random vector whose entries are distributed as N(0,1/k)\mathcal{N}(0, 1/k)N(0,1/k). That implies that ∥Su∥22\lVert Su \rVert_2^2∥Su∥22​ is distributed as X/kX/kX/k where XXX is a χ2\chi^2χ2 random variable with kkk degrees of freedom. We can then apply known tail bounds for a χ2\chi^2χ2 random variable with kkk degrees of freedom, such as:

P[∣Xk−1∣≥ϵ]≤2exp⁡(−kϵ28),(5) \mathbb{P} \Big[ \big\lvert \frac{X}{k} - 1 \big\rvert \geq \epsilon \Big] \leq 2\exp(-\frac{k\epsilon^2}{8}), \tag{5} P[∣∣∣​kX​−1∣∣∣​≥ϵ]≤2exp(−8kϵ2​),(5)

so that for our specific case, we have that:

P[∣∥Su∥22−1∣≥ϵ]≤2exp⁡(−kϵ28). \mathbb{P} \Big[ \big\lvert \lVert Su \rVert_2^2 - 1 \big\rvert \geq \epsilon \Big] \leq 2\exp(-\frac{k\epsilon^2}{8}). P[∣∣∣​∥Su∥22​−1∣∣∣​≥ϵ]≤2exp(−8kϵ2​).

Setting the right-hand-side to δ\deltaδ, we get that:

2exp⁡(−kϵ28)=δ⇒k=Ω(ϵ−2log⁡1δ). 2\exp(-\frac{k\epsilon^2}{8}) = \delta \Rightarrow k=\Omega(\epsilon^{-2}\log\frac{1}{\delta}). 2exp(−8kϵ2​)=δ⇒k=Ω(ϵ−2logδ1​).

Extending this to x∈Rnx \in \mathbb{R}^nx∈Rn is simply a matter of defining u=x/∥x∥2u = x/\lVert x \rVert_2u=x/∥x∥2​, which gives the JL property.

That’s so elegant, isn’t it? All we need to do is to sample a k×nk \times nk×n matrix whose entries are standard normal random variables, then scale it by 1/k1/\sqrt{k}1/k​, and apply the transformation to our points! That’s it! We get a whole new set of kkk-dimensional points where the worst distortion of pairwise distances is bounded.

It turns out, while the result is simple to prove, it can be a bit expensive to apply in practice. There are other constructions that give much simpler functions SSS that are faster to use. Sampling a matrix whose entries are Rademacher random variables, for example, is one example:

Let S=1kR∈Rk×nS=\frac{1}{\sqrt{k}}R \in \mathbb{R}^{k \times n}S=k​1​R∈Rk×n where the entries of RRR are iid Rademacher random variables. Then SSS has the JL property.


Proof: As in the previous proof, it is enough to consider points on the unit sphere. As before, we need to argue about the concentration of ∥Su∥22\lVert Su \rVert_2^2∥Su∥22​ around its mean, which turns out to be ∥u∥22=1\lVert u \rVert_2^2=1∥u∥22​=1:

E[∥Su∥22]=E[∑i=1k(∑j=1n1krjuj)2]=1k∑i=1k(∥u∥22+∑j≠lE[rijril]ujul)=∥u∥22=1, \mathbb{E}\Big[\lVert Su \rVert_2^2\Big] = \mathbb{E}\Big[ \sum_{i=1}^k \big( \sum_{j=1}^n \frac{1}{\sqrt{k}} r_j u_j \big)^2 \Big] = \frac{1}{k} \sum_{i=1}^k \Big( \lVert u \rVert_2^2 + \sum_{j \neq l} \mathbb{E}[r_{ij} r_{il}] u_j u_l \Big) = \lVert u \rVert_2^2=1, E[∥Su∥22​]=E[i=1∑k​(j=1∑n​k​1​rj​uj​)2]=k1​i=1∑k​(∥u∥22​+j​=l∑​E[rij​ril​]uj​ul​)=∥u∥22​=1,

where rir_iri​’s are Rademacher random variables. The final step of bounding the tail probability (as in Equation (5)) is a bit involved, so I’ll just note that (Achlioptas, 2001) (Lemma 5) proves a bound of the following form:

P[∣∥Su∥22−1∣≥ϵ]≤exp⁡(−k2(ϵ2/2−ϵ3/3)). \mathbb{P}\Big[ \big\lvert \lVert Su \rVert_2^2 - 1 \big\rvert \geq \epsilon \Big] \leq \exp(-\frac{k}{2} (\epsilon^2/2 - \epsilon^3/3) ). P[∣∣∣​∥Su∥22​−1∣∣∣​≥ϵ]≤exp(−2k​(ϵ2/2−ϵ3/3)).

Again setting the right-hand-side to δ\deltaδ gives the desired result: k=Ω(ϵ−2log⁡1δ)k=\Omega(\epsilon^{-2} \log \frac{1}{\delta})k=Ω(ϵ−2logδ1​).

entry.title: Schatten Norm Approximation
entry.content:
In Numerical Linear Algebra, we are often interested in understanding the effect a linear map A∈Rm×nA \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}A∈Rm×n has on a (real) vector space. A map can rotate, shear, or dilate the space; flip our orientation; expand the space or compress it. Whatever AAA does, to say anything intelligent about its behavior, we need to be able to quantify its effect too!

That’s where matrix norms come into the picture. You may be familiar with induced norms such as ∥A∥2\lVert A \rVert_2∥A∥2​ (maximum singular value), ∥A∥1\lVert A \rVert_1∥A∥1​ (maximum absolute column sum), ∥A∥∞\lVert A \rVert_\infty∥A∥∞​ (maximum absolute row sum), which capture a lot of information. ∥A∥2\lVert A \rVert_2∥A∥2​, for example, tells you the largest amount of “stretching” AAA is capable of as it transforms your space—to see this, it might help to go back to the definition of these norms: ∥A∥p=sup⁡∥u∥p=1∥Au∥p\lVert A \rVert_p = \sup_{\lVert u \rVert_p = 1} \lVert Au \rVert_p∥A∥p​=sup∥u∥p​=1​∥Au∥p​.

In this post, we’ll work with a different kind of matrix norm: the Schatten ppp-norms, defined as follows: ∥A∥pp=∑1≤i≤ρσip(A),\lVert A \rVert_p^p = \sum_{1 \leq i \leq \rho} \sigma^p_i(A),∥A∥pp​=1≤i≤ρ∑​σip​(A), where ρ\rhoρ is the rank of AAA and σi(⋅)\sigma_i(\cdot)σi​(⋅) is its iii-th singular value. When p=2p=2p=2, for example, this is the familiar Frobenius norm; p=∞p=\inftyp=∞ gives the spectral norm, which coincides with the induced 222-norm above. From here on, when I write ∥A∥p\lVert A \rVert_p∥A∥p​, I’m referring to the Schatten ppp-norm of AAA, and not the induced norm.

One of the interesting facts about Schatten ppp-norm is that they are invariant under rotation! That is, if I applied an orthogonal transformation R∈Rm×mR \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}R∈Rm×m to AAA, ∥A∥p\lVert A \rVert_p∥A∥p​ wouldn’t change. Let’s see why: ∥RA∥pp=∥RUΣV∗∥pp=∥QΣV∗⏟B∥pp=∑1≤i≤ρσip=∥A∥pp,\begin{aligned} \lVert RA \rVert_p^p &= \lVert R U \Sigma V^\ast \rVert_p^p = \lVert \underbrace{Q \Sigma V^\ast}_{B} \rVert_p^p = \sum_{1 \leq i \leq \rho} \sigma^p_i = \lVert A \rVert_p^p, \end{aligned}∥RA∥pp​​=∥RUΣV∗∥pp​=∥BQΣV∗​​∥pp​=1≤i≤ρ∑​σip​=∥A∥pp​,​ where ⋅∗\cdot^\ast⋅∗ is the transpose of its argument, and A=UΣV∗A=U \Sigma V^\astA=UΣV∗ is the Singular Value Decomposition of AAA. You can use a similar argument for transformations of AAA from the right (i.e., ARARAR where R∈Rn×nR \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}R∈Rn×n).

We see why Schatten ppp-norms are useful. Computing ∥A∥p\lVert A \rVert_p∥A∥p​ is also easy, if we are allowed to apply SVD to AAA and extract its singular values. But, let’s say, we don’t have access to AAA; it’s being kept a secret by someone—let’s call this person the “oracle”—and they won’t let us apply SVD to the matrix! (It doesn’t have to be for nefarious reasons, it could simply be because AAA is just way too large!) But we are allowed to transform any vector uuu with AAA and obtain the output, AuAuAu.

In what seems so magical, we can, in fact, approximate ∥A∥p\lVert A \rVert_p∥A∥p​ arbitrarily accurately by repeatedly asking for AuAuAu for random vectors uuu! The rest of this post explains how.

Approximating ∥A∥p\lVert A \rVert_p∥A∥p​ for symmetric AAA

Suppose for now that A∈Rd×dA \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}A∈Rd×d and that it is symmetric—we will come back to the more general case in a bit. In other words, we want to find a quantity XXX such that: P[(1−ϵ)∥A∥pp≤X≤(1+ϵ)∥A∥pp]≥1−δ.\mathbb{P}\Big[ (1 - \epsilon) \lVert A \rVert_p^p \leq X \leq (1+ \epsilon) \lVert A \rVert_p^p \Big] \geq 1 - \delta.P[(1−ϵ)∥A∥pp​≤X≤(1+ϵ)∥A∥pp​]≥1−δ. Also, we’ll just focus on ∥A∥pp\lVert A \rVert_p^p∥A∥pp​, rather than ∥A∥p\lVert A \rVert_p∥A∥p​ because it makes the math less cluttered.

Now to the main steps of the algorithm proposed by (Li et al., 2014). Repeat the following process T=C/ϵ2T = C / \epsilon^2T=C/ϵ2 times (for some constant CCC to be defined later), indexed by ttt:

  • Initialize u:=u(0)∼N(0,Id×d)u := u^{(0)} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}, I_{d \times d})u:=u(0)∼N(0,Id×d​), drawn from an isotropic Gaussian distribution (whose covariance is the identity). This amounts to a vector whose ddd entries are independent random variables sampled from the standard normal distribution.
  • Let u(i+1)←Au(i)u^{(i+1)} \leftarrow Au^{(i)}u(i+1)←Au(i) by asking the oracle for the computation, and repeat that process ⌈p/2⌉\lceil p/2 \rceil⌈p/2⌉ times.

In the end, output the following quantity: 1T∑1≤t≤TX(t),(1) \frac{1}{T} \sum_{1 \leq t \leq T} X^{(t)}, \tag{1} T1​1≤t≤T∑​X(t),(1) as the desired approximation of ∥A∥pp\lVert A \rVert_p^p∥A∥pp​.

That was just the (sweet and simple) algorithm. We left out what CCC should be and, more importantly, why this procedure even works! So let’s get to it!

Before we do though, let’s quickly consider the complexity of the algorithm. If the number of non-zero entries in AAA is nnz(A)\mathop{nnz}(A)nnz(A), then each iteration of the algorithm simply runs in O(p⋅nnz(A))\mathcal{O}(p \cdot \mathop{nnz}(A))O(p⋅nnz(A)) time. We repeat the algorithm TTT times, so that its complexity adds up to O(p⋅nnz(A)⋅ϵ−2)\mathcal{O}(p \cdot \mathop{nnz}(A) \cdot \epsilon^{-2})O(p⋅nnz(A)⋅ϵ−2).

Why does that even work?

We assumed that AAA was symmetric. That implies that it can be decomposed into the following form: UΣU∗U \Sigma U^\astUΣU∗ for some orthogonal matrix UUU (so that UU∗=IUU^\ast=IUU∗=I) and diagonal matrix Σ\SigmaΣ. What happens when we take the inner product inside the sum in Equation (1)? It reduces to: X:=⟨u(⌊p/2⌋),u(⌈p/2⌉)⟩=⟨A⌊p/2⌋u,A⌈p/2⌉u⟩=u∗Apu=u∗Σpu=∑1≤k≤ρσkpuk2.(2)\begin{aligned} X := \langle u^{(\lfloor p/2 \rfloor)}, u^{(\lceil p/2 \rceil)} \rangle &= \langle A^{\lfloor p /2 \rfloor} u, A^{\lceil p /2 \rceil} u \rangle \\ &= u^\ast A^p u \\ &= u^\ast \Sigma^p u \\ &= \sum_{1 \leq k \leq \rho} \sigma_k^p u_k^2. \tag{2} \end{aligned}X:=⟨u(⌊p/2⌋),u(⌈p/2⌉)⟩​=⟨A⌊p/2⌋u,A⌈p/2⌉u⟩=u∗Apu=u∗Σpu=1≤k≤ρ∑​σkp​uk2​.​(2) where we used the definition of u(i)u^{(i)}u(i) to get the first equality, the definition of inner product for the second, and the decomposition of AAA for the third. In the last expression, ρ\rhoρ is the rank of AAA and subscripts indicate specific coordinates.

The output of the algorithm is the mean of X(t)X^{(t)}X(t)’s. Considering each sample X(t)X^{(t)}X(t) gives Equation (2), and that E[uk2]=Var[uk]=1\mathbb{E}[u_k^2] = \mathop{Var}[u_k] = 1E[uk2​]=Var[uk​]=1, the expected value of XXX is an unbiased estimate of ∑σkp\sum \sigma_k^p∑σkp​, which is exactly ∥A∥pp\lVert A \rVert_p^p∥A∥pp​.

Analysis of error

I promised we’ll get to CCC at some point. Now that we have verified that the result of the algorithm is, in fact, an unbiased estimate of ∥A∥pp\lVert A \rVert_p^p∥A∥pp​, it’s time to fill that gap.

Error analysis often begins with a derivation of or a bound on the variance. In this case, we should be looking at our random variable XXX from Equation (2). It shouldn’t be too hard considering we’re dealing with iid Gaussian variables. So let’s do it: Var[X]≤E[X2]=Eu[(u∗Σpu)2]=∑j,kσjpσkp  E[uj2uk2]=∑jσj2p  E[uj4]⏟3+∑j≠kσjpσkp  E[uj2]E[uk2]⏟1=3∑jσj2p+∑j≠kσjpσkp≤4∥A∥p2p.\begin{aligned} \mathop{Var}[X] &\leq \mathbb{E}[X^2] = \mathbb{E}_u[(u^\ast \Sigma^p u)^2] \\ &= \sum_{j, k} \sigma^p_j \sigma^p_k \; \mathbb{E}[u_j^2 u_k^2] \\ &= \sum_{j} \sigma^{2p}_j \; \underbrace{\mathbb{E}[u_j^4]}_3 + \sum_{j \neq k} \sigma^p_j \sigma^p_k \; \underbrace{\mathbb{E}[u_j^2] \mathbb{E}[u_k^2]}_1 \\ &= 3\sum_{j} \sigma^{2p}_j + \sum_{j \neq k} \sigma^p_j \sigma^p_k \\ &\leq 4 \lVert A \rVert_p^{2p}. \end{aligned}Var[X]​≤E[X2]=Eu​[(u∗Σpu)2]=j,k∑​σjp​σkp​E[uj2​uk2​]=j∑​σj2p​3E[uj4​]​​+j​=k∑​σjp​σkp​1E[uj2​]E[uk2​]​​=3j∑​σj2p​+j​=k∑​σjp​σkp​≤4∥A∥p2p​.​

So we know the variance of each sample of XXX is less than that quantity. Great. We sample XXX some TTT times. Because the TTT samples are independent, the variance scales down by a factor of TTT.

Now we can finally get to our approximation error. We need to understand the maximum probability by which XXX deviates from ∥A∥pp\lVert A \rVert_p^p∥A∥pp​ by a factor of at most (1+ϵ)(1 + \epsilon)(1+ϵ). For that, we will appeal to standard results from concentration of measure. In particular, we simply apply Chebyshev’s inequality: P[∣X−E[X]∣≥ϵE[X]]≤Var[X]ϵ2E2[X], \mathbb{P}\Big[ \big\lvert X - \mathbb{E}[X] \big\rvert \geq \epsilon \mathbb{E}[X] \Big] \leq \frac{\mathop{Var}[X]}{\epsilon^2 \mathbb{E}^2[X]}, P[∣∣∣​X−E[X]∣∣∣​≥ϵE[X]]≤ϵ2E2[X]Var[X]​, to the random variable Z=∑X(t)/TZ = \sum X^{(t)} / TZ=∑X(t)/T. That gives us: P[∣Z−∥A∥pp∣≥ϵ∥A∥pp]≤4∥A∥p2pTϵ2∥A∥p2p=4Tϵ2=4C. \mathbb{P}\Big[ \big\lvert Z - \lVert A \rVert_p^p \big\rvert \geq \epsilon \lVert A \rVert_p^p \Big] \leq \frac{4 \lVert A \rVert_p^{2p}}{T \epsilon^2 \lVert A \rVert_p^{2p}} = \frac{4}{T \epsilon^2} = \frac{4}{C}. We wanted the probability above to be at most δ\deltaδ. Setting the right-hand-side to δ\deltaδ, we get that C=4/δC = 4/\deltaC=4/δ. And there we have it!

The general case

We saw what we need to ask of the oracle to obtain an approximation of ∥A∥p\lVert A \rVert_p∥A∥p​ when AAA is symmetric: We initialize a Gaussian vector, and repeatedly ask the oracle to return the matrix-vector product, which we then feed back to the oracle. Pretty straightforward. But what about the more general case where A∈Rm×nA \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}A∈Rm×n?

It turns out, if we formed the following block matrix: A′=[0A∗A0], A^\prime = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & A^\ast\\ A & 0 \end{bmatrix}, A′=[0A​A∗0​], then ∥A′∥p=21/p∥A∥p\lVert A^\prime \rVert_p = 2^{1/p} \lVert A \rVert_p∥A′∥p​=21/p∥A∥p​. It’s fairly easy to show this if you rewrite A′A^\primeA′ in terms of the SVD of A=UΣV∗A=U\Sigma V^\astA=UΣV∗: A′=[0VΣU∗UΣV∗0]=[V00U][0ΣU∗ΣV∗0]=[V00U][Σ00Σ][0U∗V∗0]. A^\prime = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & V \Sigma U^\ast \\ U \Sigma V^\ast & 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} V & 0 \\ 0 & U \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0 & \Sigma U^\ast \\ \Sigma V^\ast & 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} V & 0 \\ 0 & U \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \Sigma & 0 \\ 0 & \Sigma \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 0 & U^\ast \\ V^\ast & 0 \end{bmatrix}. A′=[0UΣV∗​VΣU∗0​]=[V0​0U​][0ΣV∗​ΣU∗0​]=[V0​0U​][Σ0​0Σ​][0V∗​U∗0​].

We would have to update the algorithm with this logic to ensure it works for a general matrix AAA.

Closing Remarks

I hope you found the elegance and simplicity of this randomized algorithm as compelling as I did and still do—ten years since its publication. There are numerous other algorithms that feel magical for norm approximation and other operations on vectors and matrices in this rich literature that I encourage you to study. There are a number of excellent monographs on the subject such as (Woodruff, 2014), (Murray et al., 2023), (Martinsson & Tropp, 2021) and references therein. I hope to highlight some of the more representative algorithms in future posts.

entry.title: Efficient Inverted Indexes for Approximate Retrieval over Learned Sparse Representations

link.title: Efficient Inverted Indexes for Approximate Retrieval over Learned Sparse Representations

entry.content:
Update [July 16, 2024]: This paper received the ACM SIGIR Best Paper Runner-Up Award.

Picture this. You have a rather large collection of (short) text documents. Passages from long legal or financial documents; snippets from novels; or articles from the web, are a few examples. Typically you are not just hoarding data for no reason. Instead, you have collected this data so that you can process it. One very routine example is to find information that is relevant to you, or can help you answer a very specific question.

Considering the sheer volume of massive collections, it would be nearly impossible to sift through all this data manually to find answers to your questions, right? That is why “search” has become such an indispensable tool that we rely on daily. We have a question (a “query”) and we wish to find, from this large collection of documents, a subset that is relevant to our question or helps answer it!

In Information Retrieval (IR) jargon, the problem of finding the most relevant item(s) to a query is simply called retrieval. To make this problem precise, however, we need to define how queries and items are represented, and how we define relevance or similarity between items. Because we are interested in an algorithmic solution to the retrieval problem, these definitions had better be amenable to mathematical and computational operations.

Vector representations of text

That brings us to the modern way of representing text (or indeed data of any modality): embeddings. For brevity, I’ll skip over a long history of lexical representations of text and won’t even begin to explain how embedding models are trained—you can read more about that in this excellent book (Lin et al., 2021). For the purposes of this post, let’s just think of “models” as some function that act on text and produce a representation, and whose inner workings are irrelevant to us.

One prevalent and practical paradigm is to use an embedding model to encode a query or document independently into a vector space, like in Figure 1.

Figure 1. A model that embeds text into a dense vector space. The individual coordinates in this vector space aren't typically meaningful on their own.

Notice the “dense” keyword in the figure? That’s because the output of the embedding model is a dense vector! In simple terms, a dense vector is a vector whose every entry is almost surely non-zero. While that is one of the most common types of embeddings you will encounter in the literature and in many applications, there is another type that offers unique and attractive properties: sparse embeddings. See Figure 2.

Figure 2. A model that embeds text into a sparse vector space. The output space has thousands to tens of thousands or more dimensions. Each dimension represents a term in some dictionary (e.g., the English vocabulary), and the weights signal the semantic "importance" or relevance of the terms to the information contained in the input.

The focus of our paper (Bruch et al., 2024) is on these sparse representations. There are a number of reasons sparse embeddings are important enough to justify (our) research. Interpretability is one major factor: When every dimension corresponds to a term in some vocabulary, it is easy to understand what the embedding has extracted and captured from its input—“dictionary learning,” as it is sometimes known, is indeed a way to gain insight into large language models. In Figure 2, for example, the word “hop” has a non-zero weight, despite the fact that it does not appear in the input, though it is synonymous with “jump,” which does appear.

Inner Product as a measure of similarity

So we have defined how we represent text. Onto the second missing piece: How we define similarity. Considering our representation of text is in some vector space, it won’t surprise you to learn that similarity is measured by some notion of distance in vector spaces. Typical examples are the Euclidean distance, and, more commonly, angular distance or cosine similarity.

In our work, we consider a more general notion of similarity that includes the other two as special cases: inner product. If two vectors u,v∈Rdu, v \in \mathbb{R}^du,v∈Rd are ddd-dimensional vectors, then their inner product is ⟨u,v⟩=∑i=1duivi\langle u, v \rangle = \sum_{i=1}^d u_i v_i⟨u,v⟩=∑i=1d​ui​vi​ , where the subscript iii specifies the iii-th coordinate.

Let’s try to get a sense of what this means geometrically. In Figure 3, I plotted a few data points (u,v,wu, v, wu,v,w, and ppp) and a query point (qqq) in two dimensions. Which one of these data points has the largest inner product with qqq? The answer is ppp, but why? Take the direction of qqq (i.e., the line from the origin that passes through qqq), and imagine the plane perpendicular to it (hhh). Start moving hhh out towards infinity along the direction of qqq. The last point that touches hhh maximizes inner product with qqq! This geometric interpretation extends naturally to higher dimensions too. Neat, no?!

Figure 3. Geometric interpretation of maximum inner product search. Of the data points in the figure (u,v,wu, v, wu,v,w, and ppp) , ppp has the largest inner product with the query point qqq: It is the last point that touches hhh, a plane that is orthogonal to the direction of qqq, as it sweeps the space from origin along the direction of qqq. Using the same reasoning, it should be clear that uuu has the second largest inner product with qqq.

Approximate Maximum Inner Product Search

While inner product is easy to define and wrap your head around, efficiently identifying a set of vectors that maximize the inner product with a query vector (i.e., arg max⁡u⟨q,u⟩\argmax_u \langle q, u \rangleargmaxu​⟨q,u⟩ ) is, in general, hard in higher dimensions. There are many reasons why that is the case, which I will not get into here. If you are interested, you can find out why in my monograph on the subject (Bruch, 2024).

That is not to say we don’t have efficient ways of approximately solving the problem. That is, if we can tolerate a bit of error, then there are many classes of efficient algorithms that become relevant (Bruch, 2024). What “error” means is that, for a query qqq , the set of kkk points returned by an approximate algorithm may contain points whose inner product with qqq may be smaller than the true kkk-th largest inner product. If k=10k=10k=10 , then maybe one point in the returned set is there erroneously, incorrectly replacing a true maximizer of inner product—in which case, the accuracy of our approximate algorithm would be 90%90\%90%.

This relaxation helps us speed up retrieval. In fact, once you get in the right mindset that error is inevitable and that we can tolerate some degree of inaccuracy, then you can often trade off accuracy for speed, and vice versa! But how do we design an approximate algorithm? What properties of data can be leverage to approximately identify the solution to maximum inner product search, particularly in the context of learnt sparse embeddings? That finally brings us to what motivated our proposed method.

Concentration of mass

I often argue that a vector, any vector, is just a bunch of noise plus a bit of signal. I don’t claim this is original and don’t think it’s controversial either. That’s essentially the philosophy that powers much of the literature on sketching high-dimensional vectors (Woodruff, 2014) into low-dimensional subspaces—I’m being a bit handwavy, but hopefully you get the point.

We started from that philosophy and examined a number of benchmark retrieval datasets, including the MS MARCO Passage Retrieval collection embedded as sparse vectors with different flavors of the Splade model. What we observed is a manifestation of that philosophy: Most of the information represented by a sparse vector is concentrated in a few coordinates, with the rest amounting to noise. Let me elaborate.

Take a sparse embedding, say u∈Rdu \in \mathbb{R}^du∈Rd , from this family of models and look at its mass. Mass here means the L1L_1L1​ norm: ∥u∥1=∑i=1d∣ui∣\lVert u \rVert_1 = \sum_{i=1}^d \lvert u_i \rvert∥u∥1​=∑i=1d​∣ui​∣. Now, sort the coordinates (the subscript iii’s) by how much uiu_iui​’s contribute to the mass: The coordinate with the largest absolute value comes first, second largest second, and so on.

From this ordered list, collect the top κ\kappaκ coordinates, and compute the partial sum of ∣ui∣\lvert u_i \rvert∣ui​∣’s corresponding to those coordinates. It should be obvious that as κ\kappaκ gets larger, the partial sum converges to the L1L_1L1​ norm of uuu. What is surprising, however, is that even when κ\kappaκ is small (say, less than half of the total number of non-zero entries in uu%u), we recover most of the L1L_1L1​ mass anyway! This is what the left subfigure in Figure 4 illustrates.

Figure 4. [Left] The L1L_1L1​ mass of a learnt sparse embedding is mostly recovered from less than half of the largest non-zero coordinates (ordered by absolute value). [Right] Most of the inner product between a query point and a data point can be recovered from the partial inner product of the largest coordinates.

That is what we expected to see. In fact, a similar observation based on the L2L_2L2​ norm was recently developed into a very effective dimensionality reduction algorithm for sparse vectors (Daliri et al., 2024). Super!

Let me refer to a subvector made up of the top α\alphaα fraction of coordinates of a vector, as its α\alphaα-mass subvector. It’s kind of a messy definition, but it makes talking about this business of ordering coordinates and taking the top fraction of them easier.

Back to our observation. What is perhaps even more interesting is that, if we take the inner product between the α\alphaα-mass subvector of a data point, with the β\betaβ-mass subvector of a query, we can get arbitrarily close to the full inner product between the original vectors! That is what the right plot in Figure 4 shows: Partial inner product between the top 15 coordinates of a query with the top 75 coordinates of a document gives us almost all of the inner product between them.

This observation, which we called the “concentration of importance” (for consistency with IR jargon) gave us what we needed to design an approximate retrieval algorithm. Intuitively, we can throw away (1−α)(1-\alpha)(1−α) fraction of data (and query) points and approximate the full inner product with arbitrary accuracy. So we have what we were looking for: a lever to control accuracy for speed. Next section explains how we take advantage of that property to design Seismic—our proposed algorithm.

Seismic

Seismic is a backronym that stands for Spilled Clustering of Inverted Lists with Summaries for Maximum Inner Product Search. Don’t ask me why, but our inside joke was that “the microsecond territory is shaking,” which led to this name for the algorithm—that name is one of my greatest accomplishments yet, and I’m famously not very creative with naming things!

If phrases like “spilled clustering” and “inverted lists” sound foreign, I will explain what they mean in a minute as I describe the two components of the algorithm: Indexing (data preprocessing) and retrieval (query processing or search). The rest of this section gives an intuitive construction of the data structures and the main algorithm that make up Seismic and were introduced more rigorously in our paper.

Index structure

Let me preface this section by noting that, generally speaking, more than 90% of the battle in designing a vector retrieval (or nearest neighbor search) algorithm is organizing the vectors into an index—although, in a recent paper (Bruch et al., 2024), we challenge that conventional wisdom. That is because, whether the index is a graph or a list of clusters with centroids, the retrieval algorithm is usually simple and greedy. So the right place to leverage the “concentration of importance” property is during indexing.

Seismic starts by building a good ol’ inverted index: A map that is keyed by coordinate index (the subscript iii in uiu_iui​), and where iii points to a list of vector ids whose iii-th coordinate is non-zero. Each of those lists is called an inverted list, so that an inverted index is a mapping from coordinates to inverted lists. Historically, this data structure has been at the heart of sparse vector retrieval algorithms. This is what Figure 5 visualizes for a single coordinate.

Figure 5. A coordinate pointing to an inverted list (i.e., id of vectors (colored boxes) whose iii-th coordinate is non-zero. Pairs like this make up an inverted index.

In the first step of the algorithm, we truncate each inverted list and retain only the ids of λ\lambdaλ vectors with the largest iii-th coordinate. That results in the structure in Figure 6.

Figure 6. Truncated inverted list. We retain λ\lambdaλ vector with the largest iii-th coordinate.

How does this relate to the “concentration of importance” property? To understand that connection, it helps to visualize the vector collection as a matrix, as shown in Figure 7. In the figure, I’m plotting a matrix whose columns are data points and rows correspond to dimensions. White space represents zeros and the intensity of the shade of each block is supposed to convey the magnitude of each non-zero coordinate.

Figure 7. Concentration of importance manifests as row-wise sparsification of the data matrix. We discard an entry from a row if λ\lambdaλ other vectors have a larger absolute value.

By truncating each inverted list (i.e., a row in the matrix), we discard entries from vectors conditioned on other vectors: uiu_iui​ can only be discarded if there are λ\lambdaλ other vectors with a larger iii-th coordinate. In this way, one vector may turn into its 0.90.90.9-mass subvector , another to .2.2.2-mass subvector , and another may remain completely intact. In other words, the importance of uiu_iui​ is determined not only relative to ∥u∥1\lVert u \rVert_1∥u∥1​ , but also relative to other vectors present in the collection.

Now that our inverted list for coordinate iii is truncated, we take the vectors corresponding to the λ\lambdaλ ids in the list, and apply geometric clustering (e.g., some variant of KMeans) to them. This results in β\betaβ groups of vector ids, whose vectors form partitions according to the clustering algorithm! This is visualized in Figure 8.

Figure 8. Clustered inverted list. We apply geometric clustering to the vectors corresponding to the λ\lambdaλ ids in the list (after truncation), to form β\betaβ partitions.

If this looks familiar to you, that’s probably because you know how clustering-based nearest neighbor search works! However, note that we apply clustering to each inverted list independently of other inverted lists. And because a vector id can appear in multiple inverted lists, it can therefore end up in multiple (overlapping) clusters. That is why we used the term “spilled clustering” (or spillage) to highlight this phenomenon.

If you know about clustering-based indexes, you also know that each cluster is represented by a point, such as its centroid. Our index is no different. We equip each cluster (within an inverted list) with a representative point, called a “sketch” or “summary.” There are many ways to sketch a cluster such as the (coordinate-wise) mean of vectors, but in our work we choose to work with the following sketches: We first obtain the coordinate-wise maximum of all vectors present in a cluster, then take its α\alphaα-mass subvector as the final sketch! Schematically, this is what is presented in Figure 9.

Figure 9. Sketched blocks of the iii-th inverted list. For each cluster, we take the coordinate-wise maximum of its vectors to form a representative vector. We then take its α\alphaα-mass subvector as the final sketch. This process is repeated independently for all clusters in all inverted lists.

Why maximum as opposed to mean? When α\alphaα is large enough, coordinate-wise maximum gives a “bounding box” around the points within a cluster. In effect, inner product of an arbitrary query qqq with any point in that cluster is necessarily smaller than the ⟨q,s⟩\langle q, s \rangle⟨q,s⟩ if sss is the sketch. We will use this property during retrieval to dynamically skip clusters that have a low likelihood of containing the solution, where we assess that likelihood based on the inner product between the query and the cluster’s sketch.

That wraps up the index construction algorithm (i.e., Algorithm 1 in the paper). Note that, we introduce three tunable hyper-parameters:

  • λ\lambdaλ : Truncation parameter. A smaller λ\lambdaλ leads to a sparser inverted index which presumably leads to accuracy degradation, whereas a larger value preserves more of the dataset, making search slower but more accurate.
  • β\betaβ : Number of clusters in each inverted list. As β→λ\beta \rightarrow \lambdaβ→λ , we form smaller clusters whose sketch would more accurately represent them, but because there are more clusters to process, search slows down.
  • α\alphaα : Determines the capacity of the α\alphaα-mass subvectors when forming cluster sketches. A larger α\alphaα leads to a more complete sketch, with the property that the maximum inner product between a query and points in a cluster is less than the inner product between the query and the sketch. At the same time, larger values of α\alphaα result in increased storage cost due to larger sketches.

These three parameters give us a way to control accuracy for speed. But to understand why exactly, we must turn to the retrieval algorithm itself. That’s the topic of the next section.

Retrieval procedure

Let’s say we have formed the index structure described in the preceding section, and are now ready to serve queries and return the top-kkk set of vectors for every query. What now? The query processing procedure in Seismic is actually quite easy to explain. Let’s focus on a single query point for the sake of this discussion—queries are processed independently.

First, let’s initialize a heap that will contain pairs consisting of the id of a vector and its inner product with the query. The heap has a maximum capacity of kkk elements, and has the invariant that, at any given time, the vectors present in the heap have the largest inner product with the query from among the vectors we have examined up to that time. At the end of the execution of the retrieval procedure, then, the top-kkk set is contained in the heap.

The question now becomes: How do we populate the heap? To that end, we first order the non-zero coordinates of the query vector and keep cut number of the largest coordinates by absolute value—the result is a (cut/∣nnz(q)∣/|nnz(q)|/∣nnz(q)∣)-mass subvector where ∣nnz(⋅)∣|nnz(\cdot)|∣nnz(⋅)∣ denotes the number of non-zero coordinates.

Take the largest coordinate (say, iii) and look up its inverted list, as shown in Figure 10. Now, compute the inner product between the query and the sketch of the first cluster in the inverted list. If this inner product is smaller than the minimum inner product in the heap (scaled by a hyper-parameter called heap_factor), then we skip this cluster and move to the next. Otherwise, we grab the raw vectors whose ids are present in that cluster from storage, compute the true inner product between them and the full query vector, and insert each into the heap. Note that, when the heap grows past kkk records, we simply drop the smallest values until there are at most kkk vectors in it.

Figure 10. The first step in retrieval. We look up the inverted list corresponding to the largest coordinate in the query vector. We then compute the inner product between the query and the sketch of the first cluster in that inverted list. Since that score is greater than the minimum value present in the heap, we compute the true inner product between the query and vectors in that cluster, and insert those vectors (paired with their id) into the heap.

We repeat the procedure above for all clusters in the iii-th list. When we processed the last cluster, the heap might look like what is depicted in Figure 11.

Figure 11. Final state of the heap after processing the iii-th inverted list. During the processing, we skip over a large number of blocks because their sketches tell us that the likelihood that a point from those clusters could end up in the top-kkk set is low.

Finally, we repeat this entire procedure for every one of those cut query coordinates. That’s all there is to Seismic’s retrieval algorithm (i.e., Algorithm 2 in the paper)! Its relative efficiency, as shown by a variety of experiments in the paper, is the result of the fact that we dynamically skip over a large number of clusters when visiting each inverted list. That is so thanks to the sketches: We use the inner product between a query and a sketch to gauge how likely it is that a point in a cluster can out-score the vectors that are already present in the heap.

Summary of experiments

We put Seismic through a great deal of experiments and compared its performance against state-of-the-art sparse retrieval methods, from traditional inverted index-based solutions to graph-based approximate MIPS and more. We paid particular attention to accuracy, speed, index size, and index construction time, and studied their trade-offs.

I refer you to the paper for a complete set of results and a detailed discussion, but I’d like to highlight one set of experiments in Figure 12, summarizing Seismic’s latency at various accuracy levels.

Figure 12. A comparison of various baselines and Seismic by latency at different accuracy levels, on the Splade embeddings of MS MARCO (consisting of nearly 9 million sparse vectors). Latencies are reported in microseconds. Seismic can be 100 times faster than existing methods, and is much faster at higher accuracy levels.

We have also made our entire code base open source, which you can find in this repo. entry.title: Foundations of Vector Retrieval
entry.content:
When teaching a graduate course on retrieval algorithms, it occurred to me that there was no single resource that covered the foundations of vector retrieval or a treatise that dealt with the fascinating literature on nearest neighbor search and all the beautiful theory behind it.

So I decided to write one, particularly geared towards graduate students, with an emphasis on the theoretical foundations of the field. I hope “Foundations of Vector Retrieval” proves a helpful reference, one that makes it a bit easier for you to pick up this topic, navigate the literature, continue this research, and make new discoveries!

I have made a copy freely available on arXiv. If you prefer a hard copy, you can read it as paperback. You can cite the work using the following bibtex entry:

@book{Bruch_2024,
   title={Foundations of Vector Retrieval},
   ISBN={9783031551826},
   publisher={Springer Nature Switzerland},
   author={Bruch, Sebastian},
   year={2024}
}
